There are two interesting things I once learned about termites:
-Despite being eusocial insects, there are in an entirely different order than Hymenoptera, which includes bees, wasps, and ants. This means eusociality evolved at least twice.
-The architecture of some termite colonies have been a notable source of inspiration for office building designs that would minimize energy used to power A/C, by instead reverse-engineering the termite colonies which have natural ventilation built into their designs. It's a bit like how those Side-Blotched Lizards have been playing rock-paper-scissors before humanity even existed.

Wow, I wasn't expecting this research to turn so bleak. I thought they were going to be figuring out how to use those microbes to process wood in some new way or you know, just something interesting to further our understanding or technology. but naw, just trying to figure out how to kill these amazing protists and their hosts. typical human shit.

Messing around with biological weapons, even weapons not intended for our species, should be illegal. We would have no control of that bacteria after we release it and it could just as easily spread, wiping out all termites everywhere. Termites are important in nature so this could cause additional ripple effects. We would also be unable to predict any unintended consequences of this bacteria. For example this bacteria could kill other microbes in unrelated species, possibly even those in mammals. For example, if this happened to kill the important microbes in cattle we could have intentionally wiped out one of our primary meat sources; the entire industry would be lost. There is no feasible means to test all the possible interactions and even if there were we know so very little about our world that we are certain to have missed a lot.
